title: ALPR Audits (San Bernardino County Sheriff)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: ALPR Audits (San Bernardino County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;

A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;

A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;

A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.

The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. 

In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records: 

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 

A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents your agency has signed under Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.

A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) from 2019 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are unnecessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected 2019 to today's date

B2. The aggregate number of “hits” 2019 to today's date

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.


Records of: 
- Officers with authorized access to ALPR systems
- Any audits that include records for the reason of the search, misuse, and how many times the ALPR search was run. 
- The number of times other agencies, including federal agencies, with access to the department's ALPR data.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: SOR and Community Supervision

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: SOR and Community Supervision
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The exact number of people who are 

1) on both the sex offender registry and probation; and
2) on both the sex offender registry and parole;

as per the latest available data is requested.

If this cannot be provided, I request records that include:

The list of people on probation
The list of people on parole
The list of people on the sex offender registry

as per the latest available data. 

If this data is held by another agency, I request the name of that agency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Wendy Sawyer.

communications.subject: RE: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: SOR and Community Supervision
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Virginia Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 8, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Re: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: SOR and Community Supervision
communications.communication:
Hello Mr. Nash,

While we technically do not have anything responsive to your request, we are providing a document in its entirety that contains similar information that we are providing as a good faith effort to answer your inquiry. As you'll see, we do have a count of how many supervisees are "Required to register as a sex offender," however, we cannot separate out only probation or parole with this report. Also, this is not checking against the actual sex offender registry, which is owned by the Virginia State Police, this only checks our own data for supervisees who are "required to register." VSP may be able to assist you in providing additional information.

Thank you for contacting the Virginia Department of Corrections.
Best,

Riley O'Brien
Records Administrator
804-584-3420

title: California Public Records Act Request: Protest surveillance (University of California, Davis)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Act Request: Protest surveillance (University of California, Davis)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

* Any risk assessments, emergency or incident response plans produced by the University of California Davis between April 20, 2024 and the time that this request is processed that mention any of the following words: "protests," "demonstrations," "occupation," "camp," "encampment," "Israel," "Gaza," "Palestine," "Anti-semitism," "Islamophobia," "PULP," or "Popular University for the Liberation of Palestine."

* Any reports or logs about surveillance activities on pro-Palestine or pro-Israel student protesters on the University of California Davis campus, produced by the university, university police, or local police. These may include written reports based on CCTV camera footage, reports of relevant social media posts, plans for future surveillance, etc., between April 20, 2024 and the time that this request is processed.

* Any email correspondence between the University of California Office of the President (UCOP), the UC Davis Office of the Chancellor, the UC Davis Associate Chancellor/Chief of Staff,  and Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs between April 20, 2024 and and the time that this request is processed, that mention the following words: "protests," "demonstrations," "occupation," "camp," "encampment," "Israel," "Gaza," "Palestine," "Anti-semitism," "Islamophobia," "PULP," or "Popular University for the Liberation of Palestine."

* Any agreements (including informal, not-signed, or draft agreements that would take place over email) or memoranda between the University of California Office of the President (UCOP), the UC Regents, the UC Davis Office of the Chancellor, the UC Davis Associate Chancellor/Chief of Staff,  and UC Davis Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs between April 20, 2024 and and the time that this request is processed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ed Burton

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Act Request: Protest surveillance (University of California, Davis) UCDPRA24436
communications.communication:
Dear Ed Burton,

Apologies for the delay. I am applying a number to each of your requested items for ease of reference, as well as, providing a response in red to each item.

  1.  Any risk assessments, emergency or incident response plans produced by the University of California Davis between April 20, 2024 and the time that this request is processed that mention any of the following words: "protests," "demonstrations," "occupation," "camp," "encampment," "Israel," "Gaza," "Palestine," "Anti-semitism," "Islamophobia," "PULP," or "Popular University for the Liberation of Palestine."

Please see The UC Davis Police Policy Manual found at  Police Department - UC Davis Police Policy<https://police.ucdavis.edu/professional-standards/policies> for current information regarding risk assessments, emergency or incident response plans.  I am also searching for any additional documents that may exist after publication of this manual. All information identified as responsive to your request will be reviewed, and made available for your access, in accordance with relevant law and University policy. The estimated date for production of the requested records is on or around November 11th, 2024.

  1.  Any reports or logs about surveillance activities on pro-Palestine or pro-Israel student protesters on the University of California Davis campus, produced by the university, university police, or local police. These may include written reports based on CCTV camera footage, reports of relevant social media posts, plans for future surveillance, etc., between April 20, 2024 and the time that this request is processed.
Please see The UC Davis Police Policy Manual found at  Police Department - UC Davis Police Policy<https://police.ucdavis.edu/professional-standards/policies> for current information regarding social media, video, and facial recognition surveillance information.  Any student related information, if existed, would be denied pursuant to The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (“FERPA”) (20 U.S.C. § 1232g).  Subsequently, they are exempt from disclosure under the California Public Records Act (“PRA”), as the PRA allows the University to withhold records from disclosure where disclosure of the records is exempt or prohibited under federal or state law (Government Code § 7927.700).

As I’m sure you are aware, FERPA is a federal law that protects the privacy of records directly pertaining to students, and generally prohibits the disclosure of such records to the public without the consent of the affected student(s).  (34 CFR 99.30 and 99.31).  In this case, the records you have requested are “education records” that contain “personal information” about a student.  (34 CFR 99.3).  The records cannot feasibly be redacted to protect the identity of the student (i.e. cannot be de-identified), and therefore can only be released with the student’s consent.

  1.  Any email correspondence between the University of California Office of the President (UCOP), the UC Davis Office of the Chancellor, the UC Davis Associate Chancellor/Chief of Staff, and Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs between April 20, 2024 and and the time that this request is processed, that mention the following words: "protests," "demonstrations," "occupation," "camp," "encampment," "Israel," "Gaza," "Palestine," "Anti-semitism," "Islamophobia," "PULP," or "Popular University for the Liberation of Palestine."
UC has considered your request and before we can acknowledge it, we need to address the fact that it’s overly broad. Even “a clearly framed request” may be unduly burdensome if it “requires an agency to search an enormous volume of data for a ‘needle in the haystack’ or conversely, …compels the production of a huge volume of material.”  California First Amendment Coalition v. Superior Ct. (1998) 67 Cal. App. 4th 159, 166. You have not selected custodians which is necessary to perform an email search. You have provided keywords, but this list is overly broad and will likely produce a voluminous set of records. UC Davis has responded to several public records requests related to your keywords. We will produce those records because they are the result of similar searches, and we believe they are also responsive to your request. Once you review those documents you may submit a public records request with specific information to conduct a search for potentially responsive records.

The estimated date for production of these previously released records is on or around October 1st, 2024.

4. Any agreements (including informal, not-signed, or draft agreements that would take place over email) or memoranda between the University of California Office of the President (UCOP), the UC Regents, the UC Davis Office of the Chancellor, the UC Davis Associate Chancellor/Chief of Staff, and UC Davis Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs between April 20, 2024 and and the time that this request is processed.

A search for responsive records was conducted and it has been determined no records exist pursuant to the California Public Records Act.
At this time, items #2 and #4 are considered closed. Items #1 has an estimated date for production of on or around November 11th, 2024. Items #3 has an estimated date for production of these records is on or around October 1st, 2024.

Thank you,

Heather Urzua
Legal Operations Manager
UC Legal – UC Davis Office of the Campus Counsel
One Shields Avenue, Davis, CA 95616
Phone: 530-754-6295
https://campuscounsel.ucdavis.edu/

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Act Request: Protest surveillance (University of California, Davis)
communications.communication:
Dear Heather Urzua,

Thank you for your email and your update on these requests. I am happy to proceed as you suggest on items 1 and 3, and review the records you can produce from related CPRA requests. I can follow up as needed. I appreciate your attention to this.

Sincerely,
Ed Burton

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Act Request: Protest surveillance (University of California, Davis) UCDPRA24436
communications.communication:
Dear Ed Burton,

Thank you for following up. As previously discussed, item #3, copied in below, was determined overly broad. I have also copied in the response for ease of reference. However, it was determined that similar previous records releases would be provided to you as they contained a similar search criteria. Upon further review of those records, we intended to release to you, it was discovered that yes, the custodian and keywords were similar, the date reference was not. Therefore, we are uncertain if the previous release would be responsive to your request.
To summarize, you have selected departments, however, specific custodians are necessary to perform an email search. You have also provided keywords, but this list is overly broad and will likely produce a voluminous set of records. For the keywords, we would ask that you narrow and prioritize the list to allow us to conduct a search for a reasonable number of records. We will then acknowledge your request and provide records to you on a rolling basis. I’d like to propose a few options to assist you in getting the records you want as quickly as possible.


  *   Confirm the UC Davis custodians you are interested in. Below is a suggestion of custodians:
     *   Chancellor, Gary May
     *   Vice Chancelor, Pablo Reguerin
  *   Narrow a timeframe
  *   Identify a specific record
  *   We can release previous communications related to the same departments and keywords to you. However, the date range is not similar.
  *   Prioritize your keyword list. At this time, you have requested:

  1.  protests
  2.  demonstrations
  3.  occupation
  4.  camp
  5.  encampment
  6.  Israel
  7.  Gaza
  8.  Palestine
  9.  Anti-semitism
  10. Islamophobia
  11. PULP
  12. Popular University for the Liberation of Palestine
Please note, it is possible exempt exemptions may apply to some of these records. These exemptions could include:

·         Records exempt from disclosure pursuant to the attorney-client privilege and attorney work product doctrine (CA Evid. Code § 954 and Code of Civ. Proc. § 2018.030(a), respectively, as incorporated into Govt. Code § 7927.705);
·         Records that are exempt due to the deliberative process privilege under Govt. Code § 7922.000. Courts have applied section 7922.000 to exclude from public review materials the disclosure of which “would expose an agency's decision-making process in such a way as to discourage candid discussion within the agency and thereby undermine the agency's ability to perform its functions” (Times Mirror Co. v. Superior Court (1991) 53 Cal.3d 1325, 1342.). The materials withheld pursuant to the deliberative process privilege meet the requirements that the materials are both pre-decisional and deliberative (American Civil Liberties Union of Northern Cal. v. Superior Court (2011) 202 Cal.App.4th 55, 76.);

·         Personnel, medical, or similar files are exempt pursuant to Govt. Code § 7927.700, and personal contact information is exempt from disclosure pursuant to Govt. Code § 7922.000, where disclosure would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy; The public interest served by withholding private personal contact information outweighs any public interest served by disclosure.

·         Exempt from disclosure pursuant to The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (“FERPA”) (20 U.S.C. § 1232g). FERPA is a federal law that protects the privacy of records directly pertaining to students, and generally prohibits the disclosure of such records to the public without the consent of the affected student(s).  (34 CFR 99.30 and 99.31).

3. Any email correspondence between the University of California Office of the President (UCOP), the UC Davis Office of the Chancellor, the UC Davis Associate Chancellor/Chief of Staff, and Vice Chancellor of Student Affairs between April 20, 2024 and and the time that this request is processed, that mention the following words: "protests," "demonstrations," "occupation," "camp," "encampment," "Israel," "Gaza," "Palestine," "Anti-semitism," "Islamophobia," "PULP," or "Popular University for the Liberation of Palestine."
           UC has considered your request and before we can acknowledge it, we need to address the fact that it’s overly broad. Even “a clearly framed request” may be unduly burdensome if it “requires an agency to search an enormous volume of data for a ‘needle in the haystack’ or conversely, …compels the production of a huge volume of material.” California First Amendment Coalition v. Superior Ct. (1998) 67 Cal. App. 4th 159, 166. You have not selected custodians which is necessary to perform an email search. You have provided keywords, but this list is overly broad and will likely produce a voluminous set of records. UC Davis has responded to several public records requests related to your keywords. We will produce those records because they are the result of similar searches, and we believe they are also responsive to your request. Once you review those documents you may submit a public records request with specific information to conduct a search for potentially responsive records.
Please let me know how you’d like to proceed or if I can answer any questions about the process. You can reach me directly at publicrecords@ucdavis.edu<mailto:publicrecords@ucdavis.edu>.

Thank you,

Heather Urzua
Legal Operations Manager
UC Legal – UC Davis Office of the Campus Counsel
One Shields Avenue, Davis, CA 95616
Phone: 530-754-6295
https://campuscounsel.ucdavis.edu/

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Act Request: Protest surveillance (University of California, Davis)
communications.communication:
Dear Heather,
Thank you for this update. Yes, I will be fine with narrowing the requests in some of the ways you propose.

Custodians: Chancellor, Gary May, and Vice Chancellor, Pablo Reguerin

I am primarily interested in the date range April 20-July 1 2024. If that overlaps with your parallel requests, I am comfortable receiving documents responsive to those requests first, and making a new request if needed for the latter dates. Thank you.

Reprioritizing my list of terms:
1. protests
2. encampment
3. Israel
4. Gaza
5. Palestine
6. Anti-semitism
7. Islamophobia

I understand the disclosure exemption, thank you. If any of the above is not clear or if I can clarify my request further please let me know. 
Sincerely, 
Ed

title: Recruitment and Hiring (San Diego Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Recruitment and Hiring (San Diego Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting records related to the department's efforts to recruit and hire new officers:
Records include digital and physical, released in their native forms (Excel, PDF, etc)

- ad purchases
- contracts with vendors for ad placement, recruitment and hiring 
- market research and data, if collected
- brand and department strategies created by ad agencies or internally
- data related to applications, KPIs of recruitment and hiring campaigns
- PowerPoint or equivalent presentations, including accompanying documents related to recruitment, hiring, and marketing strategies
- Budgets for recruitment and hiring internally, and the total money spent 
- Pay bonuses or financial incentives to retain officers
- Data by year on the number of officers, sworn and non-sworn

Search from 2021 to today's date.
Please provide in rolling production

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: School Residency Fraud Documents

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

All documents concerning reports of residency fraud involving the family of Melinda and Jestin Squires and addresses 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL and 14425 Rescue Church Rd, Whittingon, IL.

Documents pertaining to the request for redistricting of 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL.

Documentation of policy for investigating reports of residency fraud.

Document showing number of fraud claims made annually and if possible broken down by adjudication status.

Records are of public interest to determine how reports of violation of residency laws are applied and enforced and whether there is equal application of the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Webster

communications.subject: Re: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Chris,

Please call me at 618-244-8040 today for clarification on some of your
requests.  I am unable to complete the request until I have some
direction.  I should be in the office most of the day.  If I miss you by
chance, please leave a good number and I will call back today.
Regards,

MR

*Matt Renaud*
*Regional Superintendent of Schools*
*Regional Office of Education #13*
*Clinton-Jefferson-Marion-Washington Counties*

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Mr Renaud,

Please send any questions or requests for clarification and I will get back to you soon as able. I prefer email for correspondence tracking purposes.

Thanks,
Chris

communications.subject: Re: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Chirs,

I response to your recent FOIA request of the following, I am attaching
file records:

All documents concerning reports of residency fraud involving the family of
Melinda and Jestin Squires and addresses 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL and
14425 Rescue Church Rd, Whittingon, IL.

There are no documents submitted reporting residency fraud with the above
names or addresses listed in our files.

Documents pertaining to the request for redistricting of 16178 E. Franklin
Rd Ewing, IL.

I have attached the petition, secretary's report, proof of publication,
Order of denial of petition request, verbatim records from the court
reporter, a letter of rehearing request from the petitioner, and a letter
of denial of rehearing from the Regional Board of School Trustees.

Documentation of policy for investigating reports of residency fraud.

There is no policy for investigating residency fraud.  Districts have
residency policies by statute.  In instances where residency is being
skirted, districts can hold residency hearings to remove those in
violation.  The Regional Superintendent of Schools is tasked with any
appeals that result from such hearings.  I have none on record.  In
instances where violations are made known to me, a phone contact is made
with the school districts for them to pursue.

Document showing number of fraud claims made annually and if possible
broken down by adjudication status.

A search of my correspondence shows 1 file on hand for a residency
complaint (letter was anonymous).   I am including that letter,  with names
redacted due to the very small nature of the district involved which would
risk the possibility of identifying the children involved.
*Matt Renaud*
*Regional Superintendent of Schools*
*Regional Office of Education #13*
*Clinton-Jefferson-Marion-Washington Counties*

files.title: FOIA Request Squires D:A
files.source: Regional Office Of Education #13, Mount Vernon, IL

files.title: Residency Complaint 2024
files.source: Regional Office Of Education #13, Mount Vernon, IL

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Mr. Renaud,

Thank you for the prompt response. Understand regarding complains not coming through your office and those statistics not being available.

To confirm, Regarding the Squires family, there are no additional documents or correspondence internally or externally? My understanding is this has been a broad issue spanning many complaints to the education offices/schools, tax assessors office and sheriffs dept. 

Thanks again for your time,
Chris

communications.subject: Re: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Chirs,

I have no documents regarding complaints about this family.   I am not
privy to what may be documented at the sheriff's office or the assessor's
office, as we run as separate entities.

MR


*Matt Renaud*
*Regional Superintendent of Schools*
*Regional Office of Education #13*
*Clinton-Jefferson-Marion-Washington Counties*

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Mr Renaud,

I appreciate your time. That satisfies my request.

Thanks,
Chris

title: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Napavine Police Department)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Napavine Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to the department’s Flock Safety system:
1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

3. A list of network share settings that include:
3a. Flock networks shared with me
3b. Networks that I’m sharing

Please provide records in their original electronic, machine readable format. For example, please provide csv or spreadsheet files where applicable. Please do not redirect me to your transparency portal.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I request the following records related to the Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project (Map Amendment 789, Parcel 35, Phase One and any subsequent phases). I am not requesting final plans, applications, or board packets already posted online. I specifically seek non-published communications such as internal emails, memos, meeting notes, and text messages created or received between January 1, 2023 and the date this request is fulfilled.

1. All internal or external communications involving BPDA staff, City legal staff, or developers (including Dream Collaborative or Madison Park) discussing:

* Strategies to avoid Zoning Board of Appeals (ZBA) review
* Use of PDA designation or Urban Renewal overlays to bypass traditional zoning or appeal processes
* Decisions to phase the project under 50,000 square feet to avoid triggering Article 80 Large Project Review
* Any aggregation analysis across project phases under Article 80

2. All communications, internal memos, or analysis discussing whether the Harrison parking lot project should have undergone Large Project Review under Article 80, including debate about scope, timing, or whether other parcels should be considered part of the same project.

3. All communications (including email, text, or Teams/Slack messages) between BPDA staff or the Mayor’s Office of Housing related to implementation of the 10% homeless housing set-aside policy for this project. This includes discussions of:

* Whether the policy applies to Phase One or future phases
* Concerns about addiction, mental health, or service requirements for residents
* Site-level management or public safety considerations for set-aside units

4. Any emails, memos, or internal notes referencing whether to notify or exclude Worcester Square Area Neighborhood Association (WSANA), Chester Square, or other neighborhood groups near the site. Include any explanation for limiting notice or tailoring outreach away from legal abutters.

5. Any emails or discussions justifying why this project was treated as part of Plan Nubian despite being outside the published boundary, including any political or planning rationale for doing so.

6. Any internal communications regarding the collection or filtering of public comments, including:

* Use of template letters or coordination with third parties to submit public support
* Filtering of comments by zip code, abutter status, or affiliation
* Internal tallies or comment summaries distinguishing support vs opposition

Please provide the above records in digital form. If any part is withheld, provide a written explanation citing the applicable exemption under G.L. c. 4, § 7(26), and release any non-exempt portions.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brian McCarter

communications.subject: Re: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project
communications.communication:
Hi Brian,

I hope this finds you well. The Planning Department is in receipt of your
request for public records. We will provide the responsive records within
ten (10) business days. If it is determined that additional time is needed
to compile the requested materials, you will be notified within this
ten-day period.

Given the broad scope of your request, I would appreciate it if you could
review the search terms I plan to use to make sure that I capture the
communications that meet the criteria you request. I propose running the
below 6 searches. Please let me know if you have any questions.

   1. ("BWSC Parking Lots" OR "Boston Water and Sewer Commission Parking
   Lots" OR "980 Harrison") AND ("ZBA" OR "Zoning") AND ("Article 80")
   2. ("BWSC Parking Lots" OR "Boston Water and Sewer Commission Parking
   Lots" OR "980 Harrison") AND ("large project review")
   3. ("BWSC Parking Lots" OR "Boston Water and Sewer Commission Parking
   Lots" OR "980 Harrison") AND ("homeless housing" OR "public safety")
   4. ("BWSC Parking Lots" OR "Boston Water and Sewer Commission Parking
   Lots" OR "980 Harrison") AND ("Worcester Square Area Neighborhood
   Association" OR "WSANA" OR "Chester Square")
   5. ("BWSC Parking Lots" OR "Boston Water and Sewer Commission Parking
   Lots" OR "980 Harrison") AND ("Plan Nubian")
   6. ("BWSC Parking Lots" OR "Boston Water and Sewer Commission Parking
   Lots" OR "980 Harrison") AND ("public comment")

One quick note as item #3 of your request includes Mayor's Office of
Housing communications — I am only able to search records that are within
the custody and control of the Planning Department and the BPDA so any
emails that do not include someone from Planning or BPDA would fall outside
the scope of what I can access. For example, if there’s an email between
someone in the Mayor’s Office and a community advocate that doesn’t copy a
Planning or BPDA staff member, it would not appear in my search. Those c
ommunications are maintained by the City’s Public Records Office, which
coordinates records requests across other City departments.

You can submit a public records request to the City’s Public Records Office
via the following link: Boston City Public Records Center
<https://bostonma.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/(S(jn2bhvbuesn4eumcufollldk))/supporthome.aspx>
Best,
Danielle



*----*

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project
communications.communication:
Dear Danielle Cournoyer,

Thank you again for your patience. My father was unexpectedly admitted to the ICU, and I had to step away from this for a short time. I’m now following up to ensure the search scope fully captures all responsive records in BPDA Planning’s custody.

After reviewing the six proposed search terms, I’d like to request the addition of a few targeted terms to help ensure complete coverage of the original request:

“notice” OR “mailing” OR “certified” OR “USPS” OR “abutter”
“notification policy” OR “notice procedure” OR “abutter notice”
“vendor” OR “mail service” OR “mailing coordination”
“legal notice” OR “notice requirement”

These are aimed at capturing records related to abutter notification, distribution methods, internal coordination, and legal compliance.

Also, as I work to better understand how this request was routed, could you clarify whether the City’s Records Access Officer typically forwards overlapping requests to both BPDA and the Mayor’s Office of Housing when the subject matter clearly involves both departments? In this case, I don’t see evidence that a parallel search was initiated at MOH, despite its role in the project.

Planning has been consistently helpful on past requests, and I appreciate your continued engagement on this one. I’m simply trying to make sure the full administrative record is located across departments, and would welcome any insight you can share.

communications.subject: Re: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project

Hello Brian,

I am sorry to hear about your father - I hope he is on his way to recovery.

I will include the additional search terms you provided in my records
search. Thank you for your help.

To answer your question about Public Records procedures; as the Public
Records Specialist for the Planning Department, my role is to provide
access to all records maintained by the BPDA and the Planning Department.
The records I have provided are in response to the requests you have
submitted directly to the Planning Department, and represent only the
responsive records in the custody of the BPDA/Planning Department. (As a
reminder the Planning Department was created in July 2024.)

If you have future record requests that involve multiple departments or
need records from any other City department, I recommend using the City’s
online Public Records Center (linked below). The Public Records Office
oversees coordination across departments via their online portal and so it
is the most efficient way to submit any multi-departmental requests.

Boston City Public Records Center

communications.subject: Re: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Harrison Avenue / BWSC Parking Lots project
communications.communication:
Hello Brian,

I hope you are doing well.

This email shall act as the Planning Department's response to your request
for public records received on June 8, 2025. This response applies only to
records that exist and are in the custody of the Planning Department. *(See
"A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law", (2022) p. 32, n. 115).*

In answer to your public records request, please find the responsive
records through the link below:

*PRR 6.8.2025 - BWSC Parking Lots*
<https://bpda.box.com/s/uuipkwpxfjn4s46j7cbop2yfuuh2n0x1>


There is a presumption under the Massachusetts Public Records Law that
government records are public; however, government records custodians are
permitted to redact or withhold portions of public records, so long as a
specific exemption to the law is cited. (*See G. L. c. 4, § 7 (26))*

The Planning Department has exercised (2) exemptions in reviewing your
request:


   1. Attorney-Client Privilege -  We have withheld one (1) email based on t
   he attorney-client privilege. The withheld record represents staff
   seeking legal advice from department attorneys and/or department
   attorneys providing legal advice. The request for legal advice was made
   upon the expectation of confidentiality by the Planning Department staff as
   a client. Disclosure of the withheld records would be a waiver of attorney
   client privilege, and as a client, the Planning Department does not
   intend to waive its privilege. The included privilege log satisfies the
   disclosure requirements of Massachusetts law, as it includes “the names of
   the author and recipients, the date, the substance of such record,” and
   this response satisfies a description of “the grounds upon which
the attorney
   client privilege is being claimed.”  See G. L. c. 66, § 10A(a); 950 CMR
   32.06(3)(d).

   2. Privacy Exemption -  All personal cell phone numbers and email
   addresses have been redacted pursuant to the second clause of the
privacy exemption
   set forth in G. L. c. 4, § 7(26)(c). The Planning Department determined
   that the release of personal cell phone numbers and personal email
   addresses would constitute an unwarranted invasion of privacy, as this
   information constitutes "intimate details of a highly personal nature," and
   is not otherwise available for public consumption. It is the position of
   the Planning Department that the privacy interests of the individuals
   outweigh any public interest in its release.

Best,
Danielle

*Under Massachusetts law, you may appeal this response to the Supervisor of
Records in the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. (G.L. c.
66, § 10A; 950 CMR 32.08)*



*----*

Danielle Cournoyer (pronouns she/her/hers)

 Public Records Specialist

 Planning Department

 City of Boston

 617-918-4448 (w)

title: Wisconsin DOC transgender policies

communications.subject: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Wisconsin DOC transgender policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist.

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

communications.subject: Welcome to the Wisconsin Department of Corrections Public Records Center
communications.communication:
Dear Ileana  Garnand: 
 
Thank you for registering with the Wisconsin Department of Corrections Public Records Center. 
 
Your Login ID is:  186256-21263094@requests.muckrock.com 
 
If you did not submit your request through the public portal but are receiving this e-mail, an account has been created for you.  From your account you can track and monitor the status of your request and receive records, if any, in response to your request.  You can also send messages to the records custodian who will be responding to your request. 
 
 
If the Department of Corrections has created an account on your behalf, or you cannot remember your password, you may request a temporary password here: Request Temporary Password.  Then use your e-mail address and temporary password to set your new password and access your request.  Be sure to check your spam folder as some messages you receive from us may end up there. title: Peace Officer Certifications Statewide and Oaths/Bonds for Graves County Officials – Kentucky (Kentucky Law Enforcement Council)

communications.subject: Kentucky Open Records Act Request: Peace Officer Certifications Statewide and Oaths/Bonds for Graves County Officials – Kentucky (Kentucky Law Enforcement Council)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Kentucky Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

To whom it may concern,

Pursuant to the Kentucky Open Records Act (KRS 61.870 to 61.884), I respectfully request the following public records:

⸻

1. Law Enforcement Certifications (Statewide):
	•	A list of all individuals certified as peace officers in the Commonwealth of Kentucky as of the date of this request.
	•	For each officer: full name, date of birth (or year of birth), employing agency, certification status (active/inactive/expired), certification type (e.g., POPS), issue date, and expiration date.
	•	Please include any notes regarding pre-certification, conditional certification, or decertification.

2. Brady/Giglio Disclosure List (Commonwealth of Kentucky):
	•	A current list of law enforcement officers or public officials who are known to be subject to Brady or Giglio disclosure obligations due to credibility, misconduct, or dishonesty issues.
	•	Please include any officers flagged or designated by prosecutors, the Kentucky State Police, the Kentucky Law Enforcement Council, or the Office of the Attorney General.
	•	If no centralized list exists, please provide any policy or guidance that governs Brady/Giglio reporting within the Commonwealth.

3. Oaths of Office and Official Bonds (Graves County):
	•	Certified copies of the oaths of office and official bonds for all currently serving public officials in Graves County, including:
	•	All deputies, command staff, and elected officials in the Graves County Sheriff’s Office
	•	All Mayfield Police Department officers
	•	All county-level judges and prosecutors
	•	The Graves County Clerk, County Attorney, and all magistrates or county commissioners

This request is submitted in good faith for public accountability and transparency and is specifically intended to confirm the legal authority, certification, and ethical standing of public officials acting within Graves County and the Commonwealth.

I am a resident of Kentucky, and this request is made in accordance with 21-ORD-193 and KRS 61.872(1).

I prefer digital delivery of responsive documents to: pager06@gmail.com. If there are any fees associated with this request, please inform me in advance.

Thank you for your time and attention to this request.

Sincerely,
Paige Kathleen Allen
P.O. Box 322
Mayfield, KY 42066
Email: pager06@gmail.com
Phone: (270) 205-1773

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paige Allen

communications.subject: FOIA Extension
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Gregg,

Washtenaw County is in receipt of your faxed Freedom of Information Act requests dated June 23, 2025, therefore received June 24, 2025 requesting the cast vote records (CVR) for the August and November 2024 elections.

In accordance with MCL 15.235(2)(d), Washtenaw County is taking the ten (10) day extension on your request to provide adequate time to collect and respond to the request. Your requests will be responded to no later than July 16, 2025.  In accordance with the Act, a public body may charge a fee for providing a copy of a public record to a requestor.  Washtenaw County will prepare a good faith estimate to search for, retrieve, review, examine and separate exempt material, if any.  This estimate will be of the lowest rate of the person qualified to do the work, plus fringe rates pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act.  A deposit will be requested if the good faith estimate exceeds $50.
Sincerely,


[cid:image001.jpg@01DBEA94.F38B8CB0]
Tammy Richards
Lead FOIA Coordinator
Washtenaw County
220 N. Main Street, PO Box 8645
Ann Arbor, MI 48107-8645
www.washtenaw.org<http://www.washtenaw.org/>
[WC logo]

communications.subject: FOIA Good Faith Estimate
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Gregg,

Washtenaw County is in receipt of your emailed Freedom of Information Act request dated June 23, 2025 therefore received June 24, 2025 requesting the cast vote data for 2024, August and November elections.

Your request is granted to all existing nonexempt records of Washtenaw County that fall within the scope of your request.  To process your request, the County is providing you with its good faith estimate of a FOIA processing fee of $4,974.20 to search for, retrieve, review, examine, and separate exempt material, if any.  This estimate is at the lowest rate of the person qualified to do the work, plus fringe rates pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, see attached Fee Calculation Form.  In accordance with the Act, the estimate is based on 15 minutes rounding down to the closest 15 minutes.   There are 427,552 pages that require extraction and review.  You can pay the deposit by sending a check in the amount of $2,487.10 to cover the required deposit of the good faith estimated processing fee.  At this time please only pay the deposit.   In the event the actual cost is less than estimated, the actual costs will be reduced.   Please make your check payable to Washtenaw County and remit to Washtenaw County Risk Management, Attn:  Tammy Richards, 220 N. Main Street, Ann Arbor, MI 48107-8645.

Upon receipt of the deposit, the County will complete the processing of your request.   You will be notified of the balance due before mailing of any non-exempt records, the statutory basis for the exemption of any records or portions of records, and your statutory remedial rights, if applicable.  The County provides a good faith estimate for the processing time of your request to be a minimum of 35 business days after receipt of payment.   If additional time is necessary, we will contact you.

If you disagree with the response or fees, you may submit a written appeal specifically stating "fee appeal" and state the reasons for the appeal, to the County Administrator.  Submit your clearly marked FEE APPEAL to:  Washtenaw County Administrator, 220 N. Main Street, Ann Arbor, MI 48107-8645, fax: 734-222-9563 or email: FOIAappeal@washtenaw.org. <mailto:FOIAappeal@washtenaw.org>  Within ten (10) days of receiving a request for an appeal, the County Administrator shall respond to the appeal either a) upholding the associated fees; b) adjust the fees or c) rescind the associated fees.

In accordance with the Act, I am providing you the links to Washtenaw County's written FOIA Policy and related information relative to the Freedom of Information Act.  This information is available at https://www.washtenaw.org/1128/Freedom-of-Information-Act.

A copy of this request and responses will be kept for one (1) year in accordance with the Act.

Sincerely,
[cid:image001.jpg@01DBF595.1AE32E70]
Tammy Richards
Lead FOIA Coordinator
Washtenaw County
220 N. Main Street, PO Box 8645
Ann Arbor, MI 48107-8645
www.washtenaw.org<http://www.washtenaw.org/>
[WC logo]

communications.subject: RE: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request #25-1482
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Richards,

Thank you for your response. I am surprised that this requires reviewing any pages. I would expect your software to output a file in the Cast Vote Records Common Data Format Specification (https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GOVPUB-C13-5ece0a87c83a2a7d2ba2072e7420c584/pdf/GOVPUB-C13-5ece0a87c83a2a7d2ba2072e7420c584.pdf) Is that not the case?

Could you provide an estimate for 5 pages so I can understand what the data you have looks like?

Thank you,

Forest

communications.subject: RE: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request #25-1482
communications.communication:
The tabulator serial numbers are confidential/proprietary this includes the device type, serial number identifier for each voter.    With the HART system the CVR report for the November election is 364,488 pages for 223,502 people that voted.    This estimate reflects the time to do both the August and November 2024 elections.     To produce the 5 pages, would take about 30 minutes to an hour.  If you would like the first five pages of this report it would be approximately $41.80.


[cid:image003.png@01DBF65B.8325C8F0]



[cid:image001.jpg@01DBF657.CEBDE260]

Ann Arbor, MI 48107-8645

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Washington DOC transgender policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist.

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P052379-050625
communications.communication:
Dear Ileana Garnand: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of Washington Department of Corrections. Your request has been received and is being processed in accordance with the State of Washington Public Records Act, Chapter 42.56 RCW. Your request was received in this office on 5/6/2025 and given the reference number P052379-050625 for tracking purposes. 
This message is an automated confirmation of your request, and does not constitute an official Department acknowledgement under RCW 42.56.520. Agency staff will provide a separate correspondence formally acknowledging this request within 5 business days. 
You can monitor the progress of your request in " My Request Center"

communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: P052379-050625
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Ileana Garnand: 

I acknowledge receipt of your public records request dated May 6, 2025, and received in our office on May 7, 2025. We have assigned this request a tracking number of P-52379.  Please refer to this number in all future communications regarding this request. 

You state your request to be for the following: 
“All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist” 

I interpret your request to be for the following: 

1. All department policies and procedures regarding transgender incarcerated individuals particularly those pertaining to gender-affirming care, housing, and treatment. 
2. All records regarding proposed or enacted changes to transgender policies made from November 6, 2024, to May 7, 2025 (the day your request was received). 

If my interpretation is incorrect, please notify me through the request portal or email at tonja.monroe@doc1.wa.gov; otherwise, I will proceed accordingly. Please note, you request that responsive records be uploaded to you through the MuckRock website, the agency is unable to upload records to outside websites. When records are ready for production, we will upload them to our request portal for you to retrieve them from. (mailto:tonja.monroe@doc1.wa.gov) 

Department staff are currently identifying and gathering records responsive to your request.  I anticipate being able to provide you with an installment of records within 42 business days, on or before July 16, 2025. 

Sincerely, 
Tonja Monroe, Public Records Specialist

communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: P052379-050625
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Ileana Garnand: 

I am writing in follow up to your public records request, P-52379. 

I have uploaded the first installment of records, 157 pages responsive to item 1 of your request, to the records portal. Please login to your GovQA account to retrieve this installment. 

These documents are provided to you in accordance with the Public Records Act. By making agency documents available to you, the Department is not responsible for your use of the information or for any claims or liabilities that may result from your use or further dissemination. 

Please be advised that if you do not either download these records or access them for inspection on or before August 15, 2025, the request is considered to have been fulfilled and is closed on that date for failure to inspect records. This means that the Department will not further address the request, and that will be the date from which the PRA’s one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review starts to run. Please contact me within 30 days by e-mail or at the address below, if you have any questions. 

Sincerely, 
Tonja Monroe, Public Records Specialist 
Public Records Unit 
Department of Corrections 
PO Box 41118 
Olympia WA 98504-1118 
tonja.monroe@doc1.wa.gov (mailto:tonja.monroe@doc1.wa.gov )

title: Recruitment and Hiring (California Highway Patrol)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Recruitment and Hiring (California Highway Patrol)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting records related to the department's efforts to recruit and hire new officers:
Records include digital and physical, released in their native forms (Excel, PDF, etc)

- ad purchases
- contracts with vendors for ad placement, recruitment and hiring 
- market research and data, if collected
- brand and department strategies created by ad agencies or internally
- data related to applications, KPIs of recruitment and hiring campaigns
- PowerPoint or equivalent presentations, including accompanying documents related to recruitment, hiring, and marketing strategies
- Budgets for recruitment and hiring internally, and the total money spent 
- Pay bonuses or financial incentives to retain officers
- Data by year on the number of officers, sworn and non-sworn

Search from 2021 to today's date.
Please provide in rolling production

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: Fred Crisman

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Request: Fred Crisman
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act.  I hereby request the following records:

Records relating to Fred Lee Crisman (July 22, 1919 -  December 10, 1975), who was an author from Tacoma, Washington known for claims of paranormal events and 20th century conspiracies. In 1947, Crisman was involved in the Maury Island incident, an early UFO hoax. In 1969, Crisman was subpoenaed by Jim Garrison to testify in the case against Clay Shaw in the John F. Kennedy assassination. During this time, he hosted a radio talk show under the pseudonym "Jon Gold" and wrote a book, The Murder of a City, Tacoma published in 1970 through Transistor Publishing Company. In 1979, the House Select Committee on Assassinations reported that forensic anthropologists had analyzed and compared the photographs of the "tramps" with those of Crisman. Conspiracy authors consider Crisman a nexus point for a number of conspiracies and cover-ups from the late 1940s until his death in 1975. His death has been widely reported. 

Please include records relating to the June 1947 hoax known as the Maury Island Incident, which refers to claims made by Fred Crisman and Harold Dahl of falling debris and threats by men in black following sightings of unidentified flying objects in the sky over Maury Island in Puget Sound. I am also requesting a cross-reference search with the people and events described in the above paragraphs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael Best

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Request: Fred Crisman
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Best,

The FBI has received your Freedom of Information Act/Privacy (FOIPA) request and it will be forwarded to Initial Processing for review.   Your request will be processed under the provisions of FOIPA and a response will be mailed to you at a later date.

Requests for fee waivers and expedited processing will be addressed once your request has been assigned an FOIPA request number. You will receive written notification of the FBI's decision.

Information regarding the Freedom of Information Act/Privacy is available at http://www.fbi.gov<http://www.fbi.gov>/ or http://www.fbi.gov/foia/<http://www.fbi.goiv/foia/>.  If you require additional assistance please contact the Public Information Officer.

title: Arrest Data (Boston Police Department)

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Arrest Data (Boston Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records from the Boston Police Department, modified for specificity and reasonable scope in accordance with 950 CMR 32.06 and recent guidance under Chawla and Friedman:

Request Description
We are seeking aggregate-level arrest data for the calendar years 2023-present, limited to incidents that meet all of the following conditions: took place within the City of Boston, and resulted in an arrest initiated by Boston Police Department personnel.

We are requesting the following fields, if available, for each arrest record:
City of Boston Employee ID (6-digit ID)
 Badge Number
Officer First, Middle, Last Name
Officer Rank
Date of arrest (MM/DD/YYYY)
District or task force
Incident number
Location of arrest (block or nearest intersection is sufficient)
Arrestee demographics (race, gender, and age group)
Statute or charge code for arrest
Whether force was used (yes/no)
Whether contraband was found (yes/no), and general type if recorded (e.g., firearm, narcotics)
Whether a search was conducted (yes/no)

We are not requesting:

Any personally identifying information (e.g., names, SSNs, home addresses)
Juvenile records
Sexual assault narratives
Body-worn camera footage or other media
Free-text narrative descriptions

If a structured or tabular dataset already exists that meets these criteria—such as data used for internal reports or dashboards—we are happy to accept that format to reduce staff burden.

If any of these fields are unavailable, please reach out and let us know!

I also request a waiver of all fees for this request, as disclosure of the requested information to me is in the public interest and will contribute to the public’s understanding of operations and activities of the government. This request is being made for research conducted by Spark! at Boston University and will not be used for commercial use.

I expect the request to be filled in an electronically-accessible format, including for screen readers, excel, or CSV. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. We understand that the data may be large in size, so feel free to send it over in year or half-year increments.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. If you believe any of this information to be exempt, I ask you to please cite the specific portion of the law on which you rely. I also ask you to please redact any information you believe to be exempt and disclose the rest. If you need to discuss this request, I can be reached at 617-358-8514.

Sincerely,
Boston University SPARK!

title: FBI: Steve Ross

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI: Steve Ross
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of FBI files on Steve Ross, former CEO of Warner Communications, whose death was widely reported in the media on Dec. 21, 1992 (https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/21/obituaries/the-creator-of-time-warner-steven-j-ross-is-dead-at-65.html). Please include any “cross-referenced” records relevant to this inquiry. Also please perform a search of “ELSUR” (Electronic Surveillance) records as well.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John Robichaux

include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

**

FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1491928-000
communications.communication:
To whom it may concern,

I request that I be properly classified as a news media requester. I am a documentary filmmaker who has had films I have authored distributed in over 2000 theaters by Warner Brothers, and I am requesting this information in that editorial capacity.

I have also been employed as a writer by NBC Universal which can be seen on the following iMDB link:

https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2448917/

In addition, I have covered areas related to this request on the live streaming morning news program JackAM (twitch.tv/jackam) which has received of 300,000 viewing hours on the streaming platform Twitch. I plan to use my editorial skills to analyze and produce original reporting work in the form of a documentary film.

If you have any questions about my media status, please contact me.

Thank you very much for your time and understanding,

John Vance Robichaux

title: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 FOIA Logs (Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 FOIA Logs (Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the log of all Freedom of Information Act request made between 2019 and 2025 that includes the term "Title IX" within reference to the Education Amendments of 1972, specifically as they refer to sexual misconduct policy. I ask that all fields — including the subject of the request, the nature and description of the request, the requester, the status of the request, the dates on which it was requested and the date of its most recent status, the tracking number assigned to the request, and the final disposition of the request — be included.

I require this data for academic research purposes, in association with the University of Maryland - College Park. The study aims to understand the recent history of the development of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, from 2010 to now.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sarah Silberman

title: Library Contract Request: ProQuest Ebook Central at Prairie View A&M University

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Library Contract Request: ProQuest Ebook Central at Prairie View A&M University
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) The most recent contract, governing, base, or master license agreement with ProQuest (Clarivate) relating to the licensing of Ebook Central;

2) All related terms and conditions, terms of service, amendments, addenda, appendices, attachments, product terms, MOUs, MOAs, data processing agreements, and/or letters of intent; and

3) All financial documents or records of financial transactions, exchanges or obligations related to the contractual relations with ProQuest (Clarivate) for Ebook Central licensing. 

Responsive materials include all contracts, agreements, amendments, appendices, invoices, and any other documents listed above that incorporate language governing terms of use of Ebook Central.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ellen Dubinsky

title: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Tukwila Police Department)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Tukwila Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to the department’s Flock Safety system:
1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

3. A list of network share settings that include:
3a. Flock networks shared with me
3b. Networks that I’m sharing

Please provide records in their original electronic, machine readable format. For example, please provide csv or spreadsheet files where applicable. Please do not redirect me to your transparency portal.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse
